{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3407313,"name":"Tomer","username":"Tomer5614","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/7ba0ec/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-07-11T14:00:03.455Z","cooked":"

Hello to you all, our team (team sycamore 5614) tried to transfer to parallel can bus connection.
Unfortunately our can usage got to 100% when we only powered the chassi.

Is any team have transfer already to parallel can connection and can help us? Or even has some information obout this topic?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-07-11T14:00:03.455Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2414,"reads":543,"readers_count":542,"score":12178.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":468548,"topic_slug":"can-bus-in-parallel-or-series","display_username":"Tomer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"/tag/5614","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/parallel-canbus/470638/2","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Parallel CanBus","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":67203,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Electronics "},"post_url":"/t/can-bus-in-parallel-or-series/468548/1","custom_user_title":"Electronics ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3407330,"name":"","username":"noamrose","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/noamrose/{size}/264006_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-11T14:26:08.515Z","cooked":"

Hello! What do you mean by “parallel can bus”? (the CAN circuit is already a parallel electrical circuit).
did you mean “daisy chain fashion” like CTRE recommended?

page 45 in Falcon 500 ctre’s manual

I think you might find more information about CAN topologies in this thread

Trying to guess what went wrong the OP needs to understand the drawing is not precisely how the wiring usually looks on the robot. Typical CAN devices have two pairs and not one pair as depicted. If the device is disconnected, the circuit is broken. RevRobotics sells a CAN device jumper kit that helps prevent that problem. Possibly OP tried to duplicate that wiring but didn’t get it quite right.

I believe wiring CAN should be parallel as it’s safer and easier to debug, more on that here.

Tomer5614:

Unfortunately our can usage got to 100% when we only powered the chassi.

But, having high CAN usage is a whole different thing (though is affected by parallel, I believe).
To fix that problem, you can do two things:

  1. Limit you CAN frames to be slower, compromising with performance for low CAN usage.
  2. Move to a CAN FD system using a CANivore. This is the better option imo, but it requires using only CAN FD compatible devices, and costs 300 dollars.

I know the drawing is not precisely how the CAN is connected IRL, but CAN as a whole is a parallel electrical circuit, so I wanted to understand what they mean by “parallel”. did they mean daisy chaining, star topology, or different topology.

Your drawing is exactly right but I was trying to point out the device boundaries with the 2 pairs to a device weren’t obvious. Here’s a crude rendition maybe more like IRL. The badly drawn purple box is the typical device and better shows how the RevRobotics jumper can help.

I am not on the electrical subteam,
but from what I know on software, can usage can also mean that there are a lot using the can bus (obviously), from my experience, some of it can be reduced by a lot in programming.
This year we (5554), used Wagos for our can wiring and had no problems with it at all.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-07-11T20:31:08.192Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":329,"readers_count":328,"score":80.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":468548,"topic_slug":"can-bus-in-parallel-or-series","display_username":"Tom","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59306,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5554 - Alumi"},"post_url":"/t/can-bus-in-parallel-or-series/468548/8","custom_user_title":"5554 - Alumi","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3407458,"name":"CEF","username":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-07-11T21:06:58.305Z","cooked":"
SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

Typical CAN devices have two pairs and not one pair as depicted.

If you pry apart a CAN device, you discover that it really is one pair. Yes, there are four total wires coming of of, say, an FRC motor controller. But, inside the motor controller itself, the two yellow wires are connected directly to each other, and the two greens are connected directly to each other. The “T” part just happens to be inside the motor controller and not outside of it. But, that’s just a peculiarity of FRC.

Having 4 wires makes it look like you’re creating a daisy-chain where a CAN device picks up date from one pair of wires and retransmits it on the next. But, that’s absolutely NOT what’s happening. It’s a bus architecture – you put data on the wires and (ignoring propagation delays), every device on the bus sees your data at the same time.

The SparkMax CANBus connector (link below) is the most obvious place you see this – they added the two loops because the motor controller internally connected the two yellows together and the two greens together. But, if that connector ever popped out, you’d have a break in your CAN.

REV Robotics

SPARK MAX CAN Cable V2 - 2 Pack

REV Robotics designs, builds and manufactures robotics parts and components used by students for learning about science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Our parts are commonly used within the FIRST Robotics Competition and the FIRST Tech...

Price: USD 5.5

When wire can in parallel I have an extra pair of wires green and yellow, do I have to connect to them a 120 ahom or i can leave it open?

You only need one 120 ahom per CAN loop.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-07-13T02:24:47.444Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":334,"readers_count":333,"score":101.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":468548,"topic_slug":"can-bus-in-parallel-or-series","display_username":"Gabe ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59779,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/can-bus-in-parallel-or-series/468548/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"-1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3407715,"name":"Mike Schreiber","username":"Mike_Schreiber","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mike_schreiber/{size}/200098_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-12T18:26:11.579Z","cooked":"

You can leave one lead unconnected on a branch. Hope this diagram helps clarify. Make sure to insulate the unconnected leads. If using krakens with bolted connections you can make cables with only one lead.

image1364×765 24.9 KB

Gabe3:

You only need one 120 ahom per CAN loop.

You need to terminate both ends, but the rio does one end. The PDH / PDP can do the other one with a jumper / switch, or you can add a separate resistor.

Tomer5614:

Hi guys, our team want to transfer to parallel CanBus.

I see one picture above:

image912×539 68.7 KB

Can you draw two pictures -

  1. What are you using now?
  2. What are you considering changing (“transferring”)?

I ask for a picture because “parallel” and “serice” are not technical words I understand in the context of a CAN bus.

Tomer5614:

Could you tell us what are the advantages and disadvantages of parallel CanBus?

Pictures will likely be needed first.

But, additionally - something must be motivating you to change what you are doing? Can you describe why you want to change?

I’d stick to the recommendations here: CAN FD, under “Is CAN FD wired any differently?”.

Yes, you can get by doing a lot of things with CAN – by design. But, you have a certain amount of margin, and straying from this guidance eats into this. In my view, it’s better to be pretty pedantic about following the rules here, and then when something happens when you are at an event, the margin you have left may make a difference.

I don’t know how serial or parallel really applies here, so it’s hard to know exactly what you’re asking. I’d guess “parallel” is the first picture in this post, and “series” is the second picture. When you switch to doing things as shown in the first picture, things like the length of the stubs start to matter – and the stub length includes the “Leave unconnected” wire length.

Tomer5614:

Hi guys, our team want to transfer to parallel CanBus. Could you tell us what are the advantages and disadvantages of parallel CanBus?

So, naming convention confusion aside, I’m going to assume you’re trying to move from a traditional “Daisy Chain” CAN configuration to a less-common “Bus”/“Star” topology.

syzrXKG960×515 11.4 KB

As to the advantages and disadvantages of “Bus”/“Star”, in my opinion:

Pros:

  • It’s generally more reliable, when wired correctly - A connection failure at a single motor will typically not bring down the entire CAN bus, especially if the main “bus” line or “hub” is mounted in a more secure place. In our last 5+ years of using this method, it’s been absolutely rock-solid for us.
  • Easier to wire - In general, Bus/Star utilizes a “hub” or a splice/tap to connect devices to a central line, which makes adding or removing devices quite simple.

Cons:

  • Length limits - Ideally, the distance from a CAN device to the main Bus/Hub should not be more that 12", the shorter the better, which can complicate some wiring configurations. This isn’t a hard rule, and it might be fine to go a bit longer depending on your specific setup, but it’s a bit hit or miss if you do.
  • CAN FD Limitations - In general, I would avoid using Bus/Star topology with CAN FD (IE the CTRE CANivore). We tried it on our swerve drive base last year and it started having issues after the 3rd module. For short runs it might be usable, but I would still avoid it if possible (we ran Daisy-Chain on our drive system [CANivore CAN FD] and Bus/Star on everything else [RoboRIO CAN] this year)

Lastly, while not really a pro or a con, in my experience at least, any issues you might encounter with a Bus/Star layout (aside from hitting Bus Utilization limits) will generally present themselves right away, rather than during a match, so you know immediately if you did something wrong and correct it long before your robot hits the field. Standard Daisy Chain also does this, though it may not present a bus failure in the event of a loose wire that only disconnects intermittently.

There’s probably more I could say about the advantages of our specific implementation of CAN Bus/Star configuration (the hubs we’re using, the benefits of the connectors we use, how we plan our wire runs, etc.) but they wouldn’t really apply to the concept more broadly.

In general though, I think Bus/Star topology is generally a valid approach to CAN wiring that teams should at least not ignore completely. How your team values the trade-offs will vary, but I’ve personally had good experiences with it for many years now. If you chose to pursue this, I would suggest wiring a test robot (even just a basic control system) to get an idea of how it will work for you, and some of the issues you’ll encounter.

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-08-12T02:29:11.278Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":12,"reads":165,"readers_count":164,"score":113.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":468548,"topic_slug":"can-bus-in-parallel-or-series","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/can-bus-in-parallel-or-series/468548/19","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3414826,"name":"Yishai Levy","username":"levyishai","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/levyishai/{size}/264719_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-12T15:39:02.076Z","cooked":"
cbale2000:

CAN FD Limitations

I think the issue you faced was due to not putting another 120ohm terminating resistor in the end of the bus, and the same problem would happen if you don’t put one in a daisy chain topology. Though I’m not sure where/how you need to put the terminating resistor in this situation. In the end of each motor connection? Only in the end of the whole CAN hub?

","post_number":20,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-08-12T15:39:02.076Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":19,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":116,"readers_count":115,"score":43.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":468548,"topic_slug":"can-bus-in-parallel-or-series","display_username":"Yishai Levy","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57809,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team Captain, Programming Lead & Operator"},"post_url":"/t/can-bus-in-parallel-or-series/468548/20","custom_user_title":"Team Captain, Programming Lead & Operator","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3414854,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-12T16:34:30.077Z","cooked":"

No, we definitely had the separate resistor installed.

Our setup was originally configured to be connected using a hub by each swerve module, with the hubs connected in a daisy-chain path to the other hubs. The terminating resistor was connected to the hub furthest from the CANivore in the daisy-chain. When testing it, we tried it at the 4th (furthest) module and it didn’t work (red lights), then we disconnected the 4th module and connected the resistor to the 3rd module and it worked.

We tried a few different configurations but were never able to get it to go further than this, and adding devices to hub 3 didn’t work either. The exact same configuration with all 4 modules worked fine on the RIO bus (in fact the first thing we tried when adding the CANivore was to just move the wire directly over from the RIO bus it had been working on) though without the performance benefits of CAN FD, which ultimately is why we moved the drive system back to traditional Daisy-Chain.
